messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 19, 2020 - February 25, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-02-26T23:39:35Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-02-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200226-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-02-19T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-02-18.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2020-02-19.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated around 2020-02-20 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-03-03T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are only two small active regions as seen on STEREO A EUVI imagery.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-02-27.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 12, 2020 - February 18, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-02-19T22:33:50Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-02-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200219-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-02-18T06:00Z-09:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-02-18. Solar wind speed reached values of around 500 km/s on 2020-02-19. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-02-25T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are no active regions present on the solar disk as seen on the available imagery. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. Solar wind speeds reached values of ~500 km/s on 2020-02-19 due to the detected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream by ACE at L1 around 2020-02-18.  Conditions will start to go back to nominal values in the next few days.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 05, 2020 - February 11, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-02-13T16:06:08Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-02-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200213-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-02-06T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2020-02-06T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2020-02-07T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-02-06.  Solar wind speed reached values of around 660 km/s on 2020-02-07.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. On 2020-06-11, the flux went back to nominal levels.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-02-18T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions present on the solar disk as seen on the available imagery. 
 Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-06-17.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-01-30T15:00Z-18:00Z and 2020-01-31T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This minor increase in geomagnetic activity may be associated with the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-01-29. The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-02-11T23:59Z

## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-01-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-01-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200130-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-01-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-02-04T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The active regions present on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity as seen on the available imagery.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Solar wind speeds reached values of ~480 km/s on 2020-01-29 due to the detected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream by ACE at L1 around 2020-01-28.  Conditions will start to go back to nominal values in the next few days.
